conclusion: The problem involves finding the velocity of an object at displacement x1 using the relationship between acceleration, velocity, and displacement.
The object starts from rest at x = 0, and the graph shows the variation of acceleration with displacement.
The graph shows acceleration (a) on the y-axis and displacement (x) on the x-axis. Acceleration is constant at a0 from x = 0 to x = x1, decreases linearly from x1 to x2, and becomes zero at x3.
The initial velocity v0 of the object is 0 since it starts from rest at x = 0.
The initial acceleration a0 is constant from x = 0 to x = x1, as shown in the graph.
The velocity at x = x1 can be calculated using the formula v = sqrt(2 * integral(a dx)) from x = 0 to x = x1.
Since acceleration is constant at a0 from x = 0 to x = x1, the integral simplifies to v = sqrt(2 * a0 * x1).
The velocity at x = x1 is v = sqrt(2 * a0 * x1).
